areaDesc.3: Fairly clean section. No flood hazard.
areaDesc.4: Steep ascent into area. No shopping center. Some unpaved streets.
areaDesc.14: This section is isolated on top of a steep hill which is difficult to ascend in bad weather. Its reputation is only fair, although local residents are loyal to the section. There is not a vacant house in the area and 70 families were doubled up in September, 1937. This is a fair third grade section.

areaDesc.3: Good residential neighborhood of modest character. Good transportation. Near steel mill. Out of flood.
areaDesc.4: Nominal other than lack of uniformity of architecture.
areaDesc.14: Section has good character with good schools. Houses are substantially built and well maintained although the area is somewhat spotty. This is a desirable middle class section which is attractive to people who have lived in the Moxham area.

areaDesc.3: Near employment. Out of flood area.
areaDesc.4: Some smoke and dirt from mill. Many unpaved streets.
areaDesc.14: Financing is being done by seller. The neighborhood is attractive to foreign who want to be near friends in the vicinity. Better prices are obtainable from this type of buyers than other purchasers.

areaDesc.3: Near employment- good transportation. Fairly stable demand for units. A desirable section of foreign.
areaDesc.4: Some dirt and smoke from mills. Hodgepodge mixture of architecture and size of houses.
areaDesc.14: Such demand as exists for properties in this section is from foreign born or of foreign percentage. Prices obtainable from this class of buyers are quoted, but in view of the short duration of their return to steady employment few are yet in a position to meet the down payment requirements for purchase. Rentals charged are in line with the income of the people and commensurate with their ability to pay. This is a fair third grade section.

areaDesc.3: None. Out of the flood area. Fairly clean.
areaDesc.4: Isolated section of the very poor houses. Not readily accessible. No transportation.
areaDesc.14: This is one of the poorest sections in the Johnstown area. No financing is available under the most favorable circumstances. Housing is very poor and the section is desirable only because of cheap cost of living. Many houses have sufficient ground for truck farming.

areaDesc.3: Near employment. Transportation is adequate
areaDesc.4: In flood zone. Subject to smoke and dirt from mills. A very mediocre section.
areaDesc.14: Although the houses in this section are similar in character to Morrellville properties, the section is not as desirable to the class of people, who want to live near the steel mills, as the other section. Development has, therefore, been very slow and sales demand is poor. Houses are well occupied because of the general shortage of quarters. Houses deeply inundated during the flood, can not be readily financed by local institutions.

areaDesc.3: Near employment. Desirable to foreigners
areaDesc.4: Flood area. Poor housing. Dirt and smoke from R.R. and steel mill.
areaDesc.14: A very poor section of nondescript houses, many without conveniences. Section was badly flooded in 1936. Streets are unpaved in part and the general character of the neighborhood is not good, but there is good demand from foreigners who want to live in the vicinity of friends and clsoe to mills.

areaDesc.3: Near employment
areaDesc.4: No transportation- smoke and dirt from mills. Partially flooded in 1936.
areaDesc.14: A very small section isolated without transportation. Properties are built on steep hilside and are very poor. Values were never very high and shrinkage was as severe as possible in view of depreciation taken prior to 1929. Some original families are still living in section.

areaDesc.2: A sparsely settled section isolated at the top of the hill. The development is very poor and generally undesirable as a residential section. Approach to the area is very steep. Streets in the section are almost impassable. There are no sidewalks and sewer connections are not available throughout. There are less than 100 houses in this neighborhood.
Hilly- steeply up from the river.
areaDesc.3: Out of the flood area. Some remodeling of houses being done. Near employment at Cambria Steel Co.
areaDesc.4: Smoke and dirt from Steel Mills. Houses need paint badly. Steep ascent into area. Many unpaved streets. Sidewalks are largely lacking. Many houses have no sewers.

6.a: Singles predominate- some doubles and rows

areaDesc.14: There is little homogeneity of structures, the houses being a general mixture in size and architecture. Area is not desirable in point of health. Acid in fumes from mills is very hard on paint. Houses are concentrated principally near Ebensburg Road.

areaDesc.3: Desirable section although somewhat old. Inclined plane for pedestrian traffic to commercial area. Out of flood area. Clean section.
areaDesc.4: Age of property. Changing neighborhood. Steep ascent up Mercher highway.
areaDesc.14: Many owners in section rent rooms to good tenants, some of which are used for light housekeeping. This is the older section of Westmont but character of the neighborhood is good. Some of the houses are not modern and the section is somewhat spotty. New construction is concentrated at southern end. Cheaper houses are at the northerrn end.

areaDesc.3: Highest class residential section of Johnstown. Good schools. Inclined plane for pedestrian traffic. Out of flood area.
areaDesc.4: Poor street car transportation. Steep ascent to section from down town commercial area.
areaDesc.14: Some new home being built for individual order at present. This section is a very high grade neighborhood and its character is the best, but the majority of the houses are larger than the demand is for and they are somewaht old, although in good repair. New construction is concentrated along Wayne Avenue.

areaDesc.3: Good schools and transportation- fairly new section of good character. Taxes are moderate. No flood hazard.
areaDesc.4: Steep ascent into section. No shopping center.
areaDesc.14: Section is attracting buyers from 8th ward. This is the newest development in the Johnstown area, but restrictions are very moderate and the area is rather spotty, although the reputation of the section is good. Financing is available on fair terms. There is no uniformity of architecture or trend in development.

areaDesc.3: Out of flood area. Clean and not crowded
areaDesc.4: Many unpaved streets. Somewhat inaccessible in bad weather. Transportation is only fair.
areaDesc.14: Western end of the area is inconvenient to schools. New construction is expected to improve the general desirability of the neighborhood but the contour of the ground is not conducive to high grade development.

areaDesc.2: Level to rolling- hilly at southern end.
areaDesc.3: Out of flooded area. Considered desirable section of fairly new houses. Good transportation. No flood hazard.
areaDesc.4: Nominal except somewhat inaccessible in bad weather.
areaDesc.14: Substantially built houses on fair sized lots in good condition. Good middle class section. Many local residents would not consider moving out of this section under any circumstances. Because of the lack of building restrictions some streets are spotty, but as a whole the area enjoys a good reputation.

areaDesc.3: Clean section of fair character
areaDesc.4: Steep ascent into section- unpaved streets- no sidewalks.
areaDesc.13: Static- will improve if streets are paved.
areaDesc.14: Section was just recently taken into the city. Improvements from this association may improve desirability of the area. This neighborhood is surrounded by a good section, but it is somewhat isolated on top of a hill.

areaDesc.3: Near high school- good transportation
areaDesc.4: Flood area
areaDesc.14: Sales demand has never been very good in this section. Some business in section along Valley Pike. Section was badly flooded in 1936.

areaDesc.3: Desirable residential of modest character. Good transportation. Out of flood hazard.
areaDesc.4: Nominal

5.a: Skilled labor- middle class- white collar

areaDesc.14: Similar in general character to Moxham section B-5, although better elevation in this section precludes it from any possible flood danger.

areaDesc.3: Good transportation and schools. Near employment.
areaDesc.4: Flooded area- mediocre section.
areaDesc.14: Light industry coming into section along Moxham Ave. Westinghouse building factory between Ferndale & Moxham Avenues near Station St.

areaDesc.3: Near employment at Lorain Steel Mill. Good transportation.
areaDesc.4: Flood area. Smoke and dirt from Lorain Steel Mill.
areaDesc.14: Small business along Central Ave. from Dupont Place to Village street. There is a possibility that Coleman Street may be zoned for business. The traction Co. car barn is located on Central Ave. near Bond St.

areaDesc.3: Clean. Out of flood area.
areaDesc.4: Obsolescence. Only fair transportation.
areaDesc.14: An outgrowth of B-5 in Moxham which was developed with only fair housing. Section becomes poorer, as it goes up the hill. Some fair homes on Russell Avenue. Section is very spotty as is Moxham (B-5) but generally speaking the character of the neighborhood is fairly good.

areaDesc.3: Good transportation. Out of the flood zone above Pine St. Fair section of modest homes.
areaDesc.4: Nominal
areaDesc.14: The portions of this section adjacent to area D-13 are not as desirable as the balance of the neighborhood.

areaDesc.3: Good schools and transportation. Out of flood area. Desirable section of modest homes in good demand.
areaDesc.4: Nominal.

5.a: Small business men Clerks - skilled labor

areaDesc.14: Not in Johnstown city limits, although surrounded by the city. This area enjoys a good reputation but the housing warrants only a good third rate grading.

areaDesc.3: Good transportation. Out of flood area. Good schools. Stables population.
areaDesc.4: Nominal other than for rather mediocre housing. Topography is not good for high class buildings.

9.b: Singles up to $3,500 Doubles up to $5,000

areaDesc.14: An outlying section of mediocre houses. The area is not popular because of its location. Part of the section is in Dale Boro, an area not in Johnstown city limits, although surrounded by the city. Potential buyers for this class of property are not able generally to meet financning terms at present.

areaDesc.3: Within walking distance of commercial area.
areaDesc.4: Lower end in flooded area. Heavy traffic on Bedford and Horner Streets.
areaDesc.14: Section has considerable small business located along Bedford Streets with living quarters on second floor.

areaDesc.3: Near employment- central location. Catholic church and school in area.
areaDesc.4: Hilly topography. Mixed population. Section has poor reputation.
areaDesc.14: Negro concentration at lower end. Rents will be raised principally because of location near employment and center of city. Section is reported unsafe at night.

areaDesc.3: Walking distance of center of city
areaDesc.4: Hilly streets, some unpaved.
areaDesc.14: Most of the houses are very old and without some conveniences. Very heavy traffic on Millcreak Road from Westmont and Southmont.

areaDesc.3: Within walking distance of town.
areaDesc.4: Mediocre neighborhood with many alley houses on limited ground.
areaDesc.14: Houses backing up to the river are very poor. There is very heavy traffic through the section as the main road to Southmont and Westmont passes through the area as well as the heavy traffic out Franklin St. There has been some vandalism, also. There are 127 families doubled up in the section. Negro concentrated at Western end of this area.

areaDesc.3: Near employment. Central location.
areaDesc.4: Overcrowded. Badly flooded in 1936. Dirt and smoke from R.R. and Steel mills. Noisy.

6.a: Tenements- rows- combined homes and stores

areaDesc.14: There has not been any transfer in this section for sometime. Property is held primarily for income purposes. Small stores and saloons located along Iron St. Low class Jews in the section constitute about 40% of the population. There is a Jewish Synagogue in the section.

areaDesc.3: Central location. Always in demand on rentals. Some conversion possibly for business use.
areaDesc.4: Flooded very badly in 1936.
areaDesc.14: In spite of the flood hazard, demand for housing in this section is the best in Johnstown. Top rentals are always charged because of its central location. Many residents rent rooms and some structures have been converted into apartments. There is much small business scattered throughout. Growth of the commercial area is Northwest on Main street. Doctors’ offices and several clubs are already occupying some of the larger houses. Because of its location in the flooded area mortgage financing is very conservative and values were depreciated severely.

areaDesc.3: Nominal other than location. Clean.
areaDesc.4: Poor transportation- automobile necessary to commute to work. Many unpaved streets.
areaDesc.14: An isolated section of fair houses. Area has never been well received because of its location. There is some question as to the class of properties with which the section will develop.

areaDesc.3: Out of flood area.
areaDesc.4: Isolated. No transportation. No sewers. No city water. Very steep ascent.
areaDesc.14: This section is a German development with no outside sales demand. Sewers are lacking in part. Properties are largely owned by families which have lived in the neighborhood for years.

areaDesc.3: Out of flood area
areaDesc.4: Isolated on top of hill. Poor transportation.
areaDesc.14: A sparsely settled section of very poor houses isolated on top of a hill overlooking the R.R. yards and steel mill.

areaDesc.3: Near employment.
areaDesc.4: Smoke and dirt from R.R. yards and steel mills. Concentration of lower class populace.
areaDesc.14: Many small houses in alleys. Houses on hillside are in slightly better condition than those at the foot of the hill, but they are generally less desirable because of location. Originally developed as R.R. Town and is now freight division for Pa. R.R. This is a good 4th grade section.

areaDesc.3: Low taxes- near employment at steel mills and R.R. yards. Excellent school system. Steel Co. carries tax load.
areaDesc.4: Smoke and dirt from industry. Houses in very poor condition. Some unpaved streets not passable except on foot.
areaDesc.14: Most of the houses are concentrated in the first two blocks off Main Street. Bethlehem Steel Co. pays about 80% of the taxes for the operation of this Boro. Main Street is predominately business with dwelling units above stores. Real estate men do not operate extensively here. Many houses in the section are very inaccessible. Houses need paint very badly.
